utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Richard Fowler, Jesse Watters is back, and Tyrus. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." Fox News alert, another cabinet shakeup for the Trump administration, EPA administrator, Scott Pruitt has resigned. President Trump tweeting the announcement aboard Air Force One on his way to a campaign rally in Great Falls, Montana, which is coming up in about an hour from now. Of course, we'll have that for you live. John Roberts joins us from the White House with the latest. John, you can't ever take a break, you have to be on your toes at all times at the White House.

utterances.speaker: JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Your head has got to be on swivel 24/7 here at the White House. This is not a surprise. It's really been a long time coming. What has been a surprise to many, many people is how Scott Pruitt held on to his job as long as he did given the controversy that was swirling around him, 14 different ethics investigations. But in his farewell tweet, Scott Pruitt after his resignation, you can see why he held on because the President really appreciated what he was doing. President Trump tweeting, I accepted the resignation of Scott Pruitt as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. Within the agency Scott has done an outstanding job, and I will always be thankful to him for this. The senate confirm deputy at EPA, Andrew Wheeler, will take over on Monday, assume duty as the acting administrator of the EPA. I have no doubt that Andy will continue on with our great and lasting EPA agenda. We have made tremendous progress and the future of the EPA is very bright. Scott Pruitt issued his resignation in a form of a letter to the president. The Administrator Pruitt shared that letter with me. I think the particular excerpt from that letter, the passage from that letter that is important here is Pruitt saying I'm stepping down as administrator of EPA effective as of July 6. It is extremely difficult for me to see serving you in this role, first, because I count it a blessing to be serving you in any capacity, but also because of the transformative work that is occurring. However, the unrelenting attacks on me personally, my family are unprecedented, has taken a sizeable toll on all of us. It was well publicized all of the controversy and scandals that Pruitt has been facing, but there was another one that was facing him which may have been the most important at all. Congressman Ted Lou, as well as Don Baier had sent a letter to the inspector general at the EPA claiming that certain appointments in Scott Pruitt's calendar had been scrubbed from the official record because the meetings were with people that would have, quote, looked bad, in the federal record, and not keeping proper federal records can be considered to be a crime. So that was facing him, as well. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a fierce critic of Administrator Pruitt, said Scott Pruitt was the worst administrator in the history of the agency. Congressman Tim Ryan, Democrat of Ohio, simply said it's about time in terms of Scott Pruitt's departure. Again, Dana, he held on where so many other people in an administrative capacity would not have been able to, simply because the president thought he was doing a good job. The president during the campaign railed against what he called onerous and duplicative federal regulation that were really handcuffing, he believe, industry from being able to create the sort of economy that President Trump thought was possible, and Pruitt was right there on the front lines of it cutting those regulations, certainly, earned him a lot of enemies in government, at the EPA. In a breakfast that I had with Pruitt a couple of weeks ago, he thought that he was being targeted by people who wanted to see him gone, and today, he is gone. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, John, thank you for that. Pruitt's resignation comes at a pivotal time for the White House. We're also learning the President Trump has narrowed down his short list to fill the Supreme Court seat being vacated by retiring Justice Anthony Kennedy. A source telling Fox News, the president and his vetting team are focusing on three possible candidates who are among six he's interviewed. The big decision for the high court nominee is scheduled for Monday night. Meantime, the left is gearing up for a major confirmation battle over the president's pick.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BEN CARDIN, D-MD.
utterances.utterance: Clearly, the president is looking at a list prepared by an extreme group that has an agenda that really wants to just ratify the president's policies.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: So, the question is, if they're not able to withstand this onslaught, not able to hold back a justice that would reverse role, what happens? We go to 50 civil war in each of the states, plus the District of Columbia.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: If you think about our Supreme Court, it's the crown jewel. I do think that there is a risk that this nomination could move the court in a really dangerous direction.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. So we have the news about Pruitt resigning, but I really think that that's going to be superseded by the interest in who's going to get the nod to be the president's Supreme Court nominee. Kimberly, let me go to you first because the president I think is figuring out -- OK, I've interviewed these six people. He -- maybe, he has narrowed it down to three, as a source had told Fox News. And then, really, it's just up to him as the decider who he wants and to put up for the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, obviously, all the people are incredibly qualified. There this list of 20, and then he added five additional names. And now, they're reporting that Fox News is getting the same that he's narrowed it down to these six that you see there on the screen. Obviously, you know, incredible candidates, all of them could and should be confirmed. But I think the concern is just really down to the numbers. They're all qualified. Who, in fact, will be able to, you know, get the confirmation and who might oppose it, you know, in terms of the concern about -- there's, you know, the two females that might not support, perhaps, like the female justices, or perhaps one of the other ones could be complicated because of Roe v. Wade. So, it may come just down to the vote, and who might be able of those six qualified people to be able to go forward.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It is possible, though, Jesse, that because there's many senate Democrats who are up for re-election in tough states where the president won it by up to 20 points, that those senate Democrats that want to win again will listen to their constituents and decide to vote for them. I could see a scenario where either it doesn't -- the person cannot get the vote, or you get 54 or 55 votes approving this new justice.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah, probably Manchin and Donnelly in South Dakota are going to vote for whoever.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Heitkamp.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and Heitkamp are going to vote for whoever Trump's puts up there. But my sources at Watters' World are telling me it's down to two, Brett Kavanaugh and Amy Barrett. And Kavanaugh has got a great pedigree. He clerked for Kennedy. An influential guy who reaches across the aisle, not in a way, you know, as a swing justice, but someone who uses the force of his personality to persuade other justices. He's a Yale guy, a Bush appointee, 53 years old. He has really strong judicial record on guns, on religious liberty, and on free markets. And he has a long record to look through. He's a constitutionalist and people like that. Right now, he has the inside track, considered the front runner. The Wall Street Journal editorial page endorsed him as top conservatives did, as well. The one concern about him is he did vote kind of the way Justice Roberts did rule on the Obamacare case. He called it a tax which a lot of conservatives didn't like. But he looks like a shoe-in. But a strong late surge by Amy Barrett, social conservatives, really like her, as well as, you know, constitutional conservatives. She's only 46. And she's got a lengthy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not so young.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very young.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And she's got a great record of scholarship that shows her as someone that respects religious liberty, as well as the second amendment. She already went through a confirmation and got through unscathed. And I think the rack on her from the Democrats was, you know, she's dogmatic, she's going to let her Catholic faith beliefs influence her rulings, and she really expertly, kind of, deflected that accusation. But, in terms of strict constitutionalist, an originalist and a textualist, a lot of, you know, very conservative people like her a lot. And she's a mother of seven children and, again, be on the court for a very, very long time.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Concern is Roe v. Wade there, 100 percent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Would go against her simply on those grounds.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And on the Obamacare piece, I just had somebody on my show today explaining that, Richard, that Kavanaugh, what he said was this court cannot rule on that, but the four justices who voted against Obamacare used Kavanaugh's ruling and justification in order to go against Obamacare, is just that Roberts went the other way.

utterances.speaker: RICHARD FOWLER, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Right. And I think Kimberly is right. This is going to come down to the two women, the one from Alaska, and one from Maine, Susan Collins and Liza Murkowski, and how they vote. And it's also going to come down to how hard can Chuck Schumer hold this caucus together. And we saw what Mitch McConnell did two years ago to Merrick Garland, where he sort to invoked this Mitch McConnell rule where they hold during an election year. And I think Democrats.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Presidential election year.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Listen, the sound was election year, now they're changing the rules to make it a presidential election rule. But that's cool because Mitch McConnell likes to change the rules for his benefit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God. The whole reasons you're in this position, Richard, because of Harry Reid.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Call it what you want, it's the Mitch McConnell rule and we're sticking to it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, we're not.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: They're going to invoke the same Mitch McConnell rule. And hopefully, with the two help -- with the help of both Liza Murkowski and Susan Collins, Democrats will hold together. And here's the thing, it's not that we're against having somebody who is conservative. You put up a justice that's similar to Kennedy, I think you will get the 60 votes and you won't have a problem. If you put up somebody who is far to the right similar to Justice Neil Gorsuch, you're going to have a problem with Democrats and with some Republicans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Somebody like Brett Kavanaugh that.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I think President Trump made it clear, he says, quote, Neil Gorsuch was a home run and I want another justice just like him, and that's going to be a problem for liberals. And that's going to be a problem for the two women that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Tyrus, do you want to wrestle?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: My source from the Greg Gutfeld Show just told me it's going to be a good pick.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: A right pick and it's fair.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And it's brilliant.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: And the Mitch McConnell rule is irrelevant because we have the house, we have the senate, we have the president, so it's our pick.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: It hurts. It hurts a little bit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He won the election.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I am really enjoying this view between Jesse and Tyrus. It looks like Tinker Bell, maybe? But, I have big boys that have a lot to say. Coming up next, Hollywood celebrities celebrate the 4th of July by slamming President Trump, the outrage from the left, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Talk about anti-Trump extremism, the left going to new lengths to protest the president on Independence Day. An immigration activist arrested for scaling the Statue of Liberty in court this afternoon after being slapped with misdemeanor charges, including trespassing and disorderly conduct. And Hollywood liberal are piling on using the 4th of July to attack Trump instead of celebrating the country. Including, comedian Chelsea Handler tweeting her apology to the world for President Trump. And filmmaker, Michael Moore, urging the resistance to continue their revolts. And those are just two examples. Richard, why can't you guys just love America like the rest of the country? Why do you have to politicize our nation's independence?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I love America. And I think both Chelsea Handler, as well as the filmmaker loves America, as well. I think -- I mean, I think what we're saying is that -- we disagree on policy and we're using the 4th of July to talk about it. And there's reason to disagree in policies. There's 2,000 kids at the border that can't find their parents. Our deficit is at the highest it's ever been since World War II, right? Not to mention the fact at midnight tonight we start a trade war with China. There're reasons for us to protest and be upset where America is going, period.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you think about this whacky woman, Kimberly, that jumps on the Statue of Liberty and causes all sorts of disruption among the police force and the coast guard on our nation's Independence Day. She's got a long track record of doing goofy things and wasting taxpayer money.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Also, dangerous things. There's a public safety risk, too, if she fell, what could happen below. And also, then you have first responders and people risking their life because she's trying to do a political stunt. I think it's very selfish, you know. This is something that the law should not allow because it's a risk. It's not just like holding up a sign or writing an article. It's actual conduct that puts other people's lives at risk. I mean, you just can't do this. I mean, it's disappointing, you know. I don't know. People just trying to get attention. As like you've said, she's got a history of doing this type of thing. I'd be very frustrated if I had to be the one or a family member that had to go to try to rescue this woman, not to mention the taxpayer dollars which she should have to reimburse.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not only that, but the NYPD on a day like the 4th of July needs to have all eyes and ears and resources trying to protect people who are going to be in large crowds, that's what they should be doing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And, also, this does not look good, politically, for the Democrats, it draws attention to their lack of patriotism, and that's proven in the polls. I think there was a poll -- I think Democrats are about half as patriotic as Republicans.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Going back to Richard's point, there are some issues and I'm all for citizens expressing their right to protest, stuff like that. But my only critique was -- I just can't keep up with them all. Like, she's scaling the Statue of Liberty to slide down. Then you have Moore is asking for a revolution, which those words, in itself, he's not going to do that, but the people who listen to him and believe him are going to put their bodies on the line.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And get arrested.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: And get arrested. Is he going to bail them out?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Tyrus, I get that this outrage, but where is the outrage when people like David Duke have rallies in Charlottesville.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I'm with you. I'm outrage about that too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's a lot of outrage there, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But it's the same, but it's my point, so the outrage happens on both sides. There's extremism on both sides that we need to acknowledge, but it doesn't take away from the fact that there're still 2000 kids at the border without their parents, a trade war that starts at midnight.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: . and $21 trillion deficit all ran up by Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're confusing debt and deficit.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: We can talk about the $1.2 trillion spending bill and the $1.5 trillion tax bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I actually have.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're bringing up the family separation policy. And I do think that was a bipartisan concern, the president backed down and changed the policy. There is a problem with the reunification. And instead of talking about that, because of these stunts, and also calling for the abolishment of ICE, now the Democrats once again have given the upper hand back to the Republicans.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I'll actually give you that point, Dana. But, what's definitely said it doesn't take away from the humanitarian crisis. The point where the government has done so bad that they can't -- the parents can't find their kids, they use DNA tests now.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I think DNA is good though because there's also case -- we have a little problem, children smuggling, and I can't find little Tony anywhere. Well, sir, he's not really your son.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Remember, the government promised, according to HHS Secretary Nielsen, we know where all the kids are, we know where their parents are, they're attached to numbers. Clearly, the attachment number sting was a lie. And now we're using DNA tests to find them because we've done such a horrible job under President Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And we can address the children at the border separation, we have addressed that, but the point.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Humanitarian crisis.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But the point we're taking about right now is when you scale the Statue of Liberty.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Just as bad as the freedom of speech rights rally in Charlottesville.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . Democratic Party, and what that does by wasting valuable resources by the NYPD. I think it's misdirection and the misuse of freedom of speech.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Would you argue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . on the Democratic Party because anybody that looks at that, they don't think, oh, children separated at the border, they think there's some crazy woman ruining the day for the rest of the people that actually are working to protect their safety.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: So how -- does that same argument apply to what happened on Charlottesville? Shouldn't those police officers respond to real crime instead of following around David Duke?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think this is a little different than Charlottesville.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: No, it's not. Somebody actually died in Charlottesville. It's actually worse what happened in Charlottesville.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I understand. I understand.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Don't mix apples and oranges here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. These are two separate situations.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: No, they're really not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So we're going to go to break. The Democratic Party officially endorses socialism, the video up next.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: The battle for the future of the Democratic Party is on, just a week after 28-year-old Democratic socialist Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez stunning primary win. DNC Chairman Tom Perez is embracing her as the future of the party.

utterances.speaker: TOM PEREZ, DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN
utterances.utterance: I have three kids, two of whom are daughters. One just graduated college, one is in college, and they were both texting me about their excitement over Alexandria because, you know, she really -- she represents the future of our party.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, new poll shows Dems are undecided about a leader for 2020. And let me just say, it is way too early for Dems -- we're supposed to be undecided. Donald Trump was not the leader of the party at this point in time in his career. Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, so no need to hit the panic button, right, for the Democrats?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: No, not at all.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, there should be cause for concern because they don't have, so far, a candidate that's emerge. They don't have, really, a platform that seems united. There seems to be, really, such a push toward liberal like extremism to the point where you've got theatrics like climbing the Statue of Liberty, you've got calls for, you know, violence, you really don't have a platform agenda. I mean, what is it? You know, don't make the economy great? Like, undo that?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, come on. I think our agenda is pretty clear. We want affordable healthcare, we want high quality public education. We wants ends to meet for working family. I think we have a very clear agenda. We think prescription drug costs are too high and we think Republicans are doing nothing about it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think if you guys had it making healthcare affordable and it bombed.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: You guys had two years to fix it and had done nothing. What have you all done?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But, Richard, if the future of the Democratic Party is socialism, then the Democratic Party has no future. This woman is a bright woman. She's very attractive, and young and energetic. But she shouldn't be the future of the party. She's extreme left. She represents a very small radical base in the Bronx. And now, she's being tapped as some mini- celebrity within the party and her endorsements actually matter. I'm shocked. I would love to see her face someone like Bret Baier, face a tough interview where she actually has to explain -- Watters' World, open invitation, explain her positions and say how she's going to pay for it. I don't know if she has that inside of her yet. But it's a little too young to think.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: . and very tough journalist and she's answered all those questions, number one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Poppy who?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Number two -- number two and more importantly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Poppy who? I don't even know who that is.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Well, you should pay more attention. Number two, I think the Republicans are running their fair share of far right candidates including Corey Stewart who is a alt-right out of Virginia who is the nominee for senate. Who is literally pals around with racists.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He doesn't want to abolish ICE. That I know.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: So, you're OK with endorsing a racist?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know who he is?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And he uses the words Yankees and southerners.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But either way, like I said, Democrats are going to run 435 different races, and what Ms. Cortez is running is the New York is going to be very different. What we're running in Alabama, what we're running in Missouri, we're going to run different races all across the country just like you guys are doing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I wish you best of luck, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And we're going to win.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Point is it's early. It's too early. And number one, if I was part of the Democratic Party and I had dark horse candidate I thought would do some things, I would keep them under wraps too. Do you really want to stick your head out of the rabbit hole this early and have to deal with Donald Trump for the next two years going after you?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: So, if you do have somebody, keep it on the D-low. Just keep it low. That would be my advice. I'm not here to argue.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Graphic right there, Dems divided. I mean, that really is just a beautiful graphic, isn't it? It's Big. It's beautiful.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But I think none of these are going to be the nominee for our party in 2020.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Nevertheless.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The whole ideology that they're divided, extremisms, socialism.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: So are the Republicans. You guys are running a race out of Virginia. He's a racist for senate out of Virginia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I do think that, Richard, if she gets too problematic for the Democratic Party, they're going to knee cap her Bernie Sanders style. They're going to rigged it against her because the establishment can't afford to have some sort of lightning rod that's going to divide the party and go against Wall Street.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I find it hard to believe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . and make everybody else look bad.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I think she's going to win and be the next congresswoman from that district.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I do, too, but not the nominee.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would say that one big difference -- you make a good point about Corey Stewart, but it's not the exact same -- it was Tom Perez, the head of the DNC, who said she's the future of the party. Ronna McDaniel has not said that Corey Stewart is the future of the Republican Party.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But the president has tweeted about him. I mean, isn't the president the head of the party?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't think that he's tweeted on him since.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: He's tweeted about -- primaries saying congrats and look forward to you winning.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I am not for him.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Somebody probably whisper in his ears and he probably went, oh, damn, never mind.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The other thing is, though, I think that you also see there is an age problem with the Democrats that leadership, Pelosi, Hoyer, and Clyburn, they're collective ages is 234 years. And, you see the restlessness, Tom Perez talks about his daughter and all the Bernie bros -- everybody was like so young. And there is a divide. And I think the grass-roots are angry, they're frustrated, it reminds me a lot of the tea party movement. And so, the establishment Democrats are having to figure out how they can bring in this new, young talent, that still win elections, and that might not be all that easy.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And I think we're doing it, though. I think if you look -- we're running veterans. We're fronting new faces.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I know.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: . all across the country. And that's why we're going to win this primary. We're going to win back the house pretty easily.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But it makes it hard for the people, like MJ Hager, who has then to defend against somebody like Maxine Waters calling for all of these harassments.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: With all due respect, as long as the economy is swole [SIC] like my arms --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: -- I don't care who you have running. It's not going to happen. Like the economy --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Better your arms than my arms.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: And we'll keep it -- as long as you've got good economy, the Republicans are fine.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I mean, we'll find out at midnight when we start our trade war with China.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness. That's -- OK.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Coming up, companies are starting to embrace the idea of sleeping on the job. That's next.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: You may remember this classic scene from the movie "Office Space."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Corporate accounts payable, Nina speaking. Just a moment. Corporate accounts payable, Nina speaking. Just a moment. Corporate accounts payable, Nina speaking. Just a moment.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: As you can see, thee's distractions in the work place. All those e-mails and phone calls we're bombarded with everyday can put a strain on your productivity and your brain. Research estimates it can reduce your workplace I.Q. by 10 points, the equivalent of losing a night's sleep. So how can we get employees in the best mental state? How about a nice nap? A growing number of companies are encouraging sleeping on the job, with high-tech napping pods and rooms to make a more productive work place.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're not buying this? Very skeptical.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: No. I don't believe this for one second. No, there's just too much watching "World Star" and arguing with your girl in Texas, and too many WhatsUp apps and all that kind of stuff and people doing stuff, working on their own careers. Their writers, their acting gigs and all the stuff that I do behind the scenes at "The Greg Gutfeld Show." So this -- this -- this --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That was a great read, though.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I liked it. You really conveyed sort of your thought process.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: You feel like I captured the art of --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I totally did.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: -- embracing taking a nap at work --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The tone, you felt it?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: -- which most of us who were in our first jobs did nap at work, and that's why we didn't keep our jobs. So I have -- I have issues with this. Like, if you have a security job, you've kind of got to stay awake, right? Or you're watching a nuclear plant, can you take a nap?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No. Unlike -- unless you're Homer Simpson.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He can fall asleep on the job. I don't want us to spend money on napping pods. I think that sounds bad. And you can't really do that in the news business.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Could you imagine?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You've got to stay ahead of the curve.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Napping now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would want -- I do want kind of like a hot food station here at FOX. Right now we have salad stations, and then they do the sandwich and they put on a hot press. But like, what about a burger or a hot dog or something on the grill? If we could incorporate that instead of the napping pod.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: So you're going to add -- I'm sorry, you're going to add (UNINTELLIGIBLE) to the argument, which you eat a lot of heavy meat, you go to sleep. So that's wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't fall asleep. I perform better when I've had protein.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I've never heard of that. Dana, you're a multitasker, correct?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, actually, the truth is --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Would you struggle?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I actually believe that it is impossible to multitask. So if you are trying to do several different things at once and you think you're handling it, the truth is, you're really not. And the better way to do work is to focus on that one thing, and then maybe get up and, like, make the phone calls or look at Twitter, whatever, but then to come back and focus. Because multitasking is not real. It's not - - it doesn't really happen.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I know you can multitask.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I can, but I actually agree with Dana on this. I think the most productive I am, especially when I'm prepping for this, when I'm prepping for "The Five," I call it work block. Where I don't answer my phone and I don't check e-mail. I just prep for the show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You prep for the show?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow, what's that like?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Watters, we know -- we know you don't prep for the show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is you prepared? I'd hate to see you unprepared.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: You don't prepare because you're --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Somebody is spicy. Order in the court.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Throwing a lot of shade.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: -- this happening right here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm kidding.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Bail me out, K.G.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: don't know, we need a lot of help right now with this. Jesse is throwing shade. I don't know. Richard, you seem very prepared.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like because we didn't grow up with phones, and they're new to us, though. But when you are raising a youngster --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- like your son, how do you make sure that he can do his homework without worrying about any sort of social -- not that he's on social media. But --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right, right, right. But he has a schedule.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right? And I think it's very good, like much like we train dogs, you know, children. And people respond well to a schedule. So he knows, like, when he comes home, his time, like, for a snack, right? He gets to eat something before he does homework. And then after he does his homework, and I've checked it, then he can go ahead and do something that's like recreational, play a game or, you know, go outside, etcetera. It just depends. And he responds to that. Then he eats dinner at a certain time. Then he takes a shower every night.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How much did the Pavlov dog --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But look at how well he's turned out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When he does his homework, his mouth starts watering.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: She's guilty (ph). She's Multitasking.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Then he takes shower. He has an after-dinner healthy snack like sliced apples or something like that, and then he goes to bed at a certain time.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I need to get my life in order.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Jesse, that actually might work for you. That might keep you on task.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: We just talked about getting a good night's sleep. Did you get your eight hours in? Supposedly, that will help you be more productive at work. So stop staying up late binge-watching --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Netflix.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Or "The Greg Gutfeld Show."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or looking at your phone.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, or staring at your phone. Staying up late and not getting enough sleep does affect you in your workplace.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: You've got to get your eight hours in.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I overheard, on the day off yesterday, on the Fourth of July, I overheard this younger girl. She was probably, like, 21 --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: You were eavesdropping?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, no, she was very loud.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But she -- she said that -- it was something like 10 a.m. And they said, "Oh, are you just getting up?" And she said, "Well, I need my 10 hours of sleep. I heard it on a podcast."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's very good for children, too, to get sleep.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a lot.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, if you're 6, ten hours is great.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: But if you're an adult, you get your behind up and get to work.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, but for a child, you pay attention in school. And if you get a good night's rest, and you're on schedule, because a lot of children that suffer from, like, attention deficit disorder or different things or learning differences, it really helps if you have a schedule and you have that structure and get rest.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: So no one here is in favor of naps?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I'm in favor of the power nap.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, but not at work.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: One time you could be in the group, you just won't do it.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: No, I will not.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Very Juan of you. Very Juan of you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's the difference between power nap, though, and a regular nap?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Power nap is --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Seven minutes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Twenty to 30 minutes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's shorter in duration.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: A regular nap is 90 minutes?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thirty minutes?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A regular nap is 90.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's, like, five news cycles in 30 minutes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wait, who -- really?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: There's a nap commission.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I thought there's like a science of -- I don't know.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: The science to have, like, a 30-minute nap so you get all the cycles right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know who was a great napper?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: What about resting your eyes? What is does that fall under? Because I'm good at that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Margaret Thatcher was an excellent power napper. She could just take, like, two or three minutes, and then she'd be back and ready to go.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's amazing.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: All right. FOX News alert, President Trump just landed in Great Falls, Montana, ahead of his "Make America Great Again" rally, coming up at the top of the hour. We'll bring it to you live when it happens. Stay tuned to FOX News. There's a guy walking.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, we're talking?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, it doesn't say --

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: So power naps.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So Jesse, the president just arrived in Montana.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, so big rally tonight, 6 p.m., and I think it's going to be probably another stem winder, which will have the liberals apoplectic. And these rallies, he really connects with the base. Probably FOX News will take it live in full, and CNN will not take it and get destroyed in the ratings.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Let's talk about the race.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're going to see more of the president.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Let's talk about the facts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, let me just finish. You're going to see more of the president coming up into the mid-terms on the road, connecting with the audience in these states where they need to flip the Democratic seats.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Well, the seat is actually going to be --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Putting a lot of pressure on these Democrats in these districts.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: This -- so this seat is actually going to be very hard to flip. He's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. I have news. I'm told that -- so apparently, the president did a gaggle with reporters on the plane, and it was a couple days ago that he talked to Scott Pruitt, the now resigned EPA administrator. So the president that this resignation was coming. He was expecting it, and it is effective tomorrow, the sixth of July.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, some of his scandals were a little silly, like one of his scandals, that he made his staff get him snacks. I mean, if anybody's worked for any boss, the boss will sometimes make you get snacks. On the other hand, another scandal --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: That's not against the law, though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, Richard, just relax.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But it's against the law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Another scandal, he spent $30,000 of taxpayer money on soundproofing his office, not a good look.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: How about the $5,000 on pens and journals?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's a lot of money on pens and journals.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Or sending his staff to buy a used mattress from the Trump Hotel.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to defend Scott Pruitt's spending.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But he's part of the Trump swamp.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I will say that it's going to be a smooth transition.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Well, he just got drained, though. That's a good thing, because he just got drained.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Two years. You can take --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: His -- his deputy is pretty good, and the Trump administration's environmental policies and conservation policies will still remain the same.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But I thought Trump -- I mean, I thought Trump, like, sort of ran on the whole idea of draining the swamp, and this guy is the epitome of the swamp.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, he's not there anymore.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's not there anymore.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Well, you can take a horse to water, but you can't make him fish. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This -- yes.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Joey Chestnut consumes over 20,000 calories in 10 minutes at this year's Fourth hot dog eating contest. Wow. "Kimberly's Food Court" is next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is a FOX News alert. President Trump arriving in Montana for a campaign rally. And he's commenting on the resignation of EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt, saying the White House has been talking about it for a while, and it has been in the works for a couple of days. We're keeping an eye on that. But right now, it's time for "Kimberly's Food Court." Yes. All right. Well, he is the hot dog eating king once again. You know him, right? Joey Chestnut chowing down a record 74 hot dogs in 10 minutes at the Nathan's Famous July Fourth hot dog eating contest at New York's Coney Island boardwalk. It was the 11th time he won the coveted mustard belt. God, I wish I had that. Meanwhile, in the women's competition, Miki Sudo bested her competition by eating 37 hot dogs in three -- oh, 10 minutes. Well, that is pretty impressive.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Three minutes would have been amazing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think she's -- that's going to be --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I can't even watch that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Can you imagine? I think it's very impressive. It takes a lot of mental discipline to be able to eat that quickly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: An amazing --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is a gorgeous graphic behind you. I just wish you would feast your eyes on this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's pretty amazing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, and you know, as a competitive eater, that I am, I can tell you the preparation that goes in mentally, like, the night before. And you've got to be careful about your diet, what you have before you go into these competitions. We all were talking about what would he be, you know, competitive with, if we were going to be in one of these. Obviously, I feel very well-versed to do chicken wings, because I am the reigning champion around these parts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She is. Don't ever bet against her.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Dana --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Always ask her to be on your team. It's -- I've never seen anything like it. She is a competitor of the highest degree.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Highest order.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You'd want her on your team.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm not playing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: "I'm not playing"?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I'm not eating that many hot dogs for nobody. I just -- I don't look at it as a real sport.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What did you choose if you were to have something?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I chose pie, because everyone loves pie. But real quick, I actually did win a food eating contest one time in Laredo, Texas. I beat John Cena in a 72-ounce steak eating contest.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No way.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Smashed him.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's pretty cool.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How long did it take?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: It was about -- about 30 minutes. A lot of side bets, but I was people's champion that night.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're going to take a sample over there? No. Oh, you have the pie. Dana, this was hysterical.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I thought this was pretty funny, that I -- if I were to choose, like, what I could eat to win, I chose M&M's.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: You could eat like three?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No. You could eat a whole bunch of M&M's. If you're going by the number, then I could actually probably win if I did something like that.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: You'd have to use two hands to eat one M&M.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is hysterical. It's like, she's, like, cute and little, and like the M&M's are little.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I want to give these -- I'm giving these to Jesse for his office.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He'll eat all of those, for sure. Jess, what did you pick?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I got McNuggets.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, you love those.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I was going to get shellfish, but I got scolded one time for doing that. So I went with --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Your first week.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Chicken nuggets and barbecue sauce, and I'm ready to take on all challengers. I know I'm the newcomer to the table, but that belt is not secure. That mustard belt, Kimberly --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I might be wearing that at the end of the show.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Are you talking about to compete with me? Because that would be foolish idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Would we have the same food or would we compete nuggets versus wings? How would it go down?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, I think either way, you would lose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Are we doing this then? Because Richard chose shrimp cocktail. Which is ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I did. I chose shrimp. Because --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is a salad.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How are you going to eat that?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: You totally botched this.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I'm going to still beat y'all. Don't under -- don't underestimate me, America. Don't underestimate me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In the minute or so that we have, should we -- should we have a throwdown?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm just going to start.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Go.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: His are, like, soft. Mine have all the hard part on there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Who do you think is going to win?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: I don't care. I'm going to eat pie.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Let them eat pie. Let them eat cake.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What did you say, Mina? Oh, one minute. OK, go.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Dana, you're not doing any of it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I'm not, because I'm emceeing this event.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: She can't. They're way too big for her.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Richard might win, because he is, like, throwing down, all that --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I'm telling you, shrimp is the way to go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse is kind of disappointing me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't feel so well.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Look at -- look at, I'm going to win.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Low calories, people. Low calories.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: It's not even close.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This was a bad idea.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a big bite that you just took out of that pie.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: But I'm taking my time. It's pie. So you know --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow. She's going to win.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's not even close.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I'm in the lead here. I only have, like, two shrimps left.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I underestimated Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I've told you, never, never bet against her.

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: But you've got to eat all the salad, too, bro.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: No, that's not part of the rules. It is just approaching.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's just approaching.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, man. I don't feel so good.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Winner, winner, chicken dinner. "One More Thing" up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: President Trump is on his way to a campaign rally in Montana. It's set to start at the top of the hour. Right now, it's time for "One More Thing." I'm going to go first, because I have a special guest. This is Spike. He's a service puppy for Canine Companions for Independents. He's really into Tyrus's arms. These are dogs that are much-needed. And the producer of "The Daily Briefing," Jen Williams, she's here, over there taking pictures. This is a five-month-old puppy that she is raising. She will take care of him for 18 months and make sure he hits all of his benchmarks, all the training. And then after that he goes to more specific training, where he will learn how to open doors, turn on and off lights, and learn how to take care of someone. Jen has had him since he was eight weeks old. And if you go to FOXNews.com/TheDailySpike, you'll learn more about Canine Companions for Independence. That's CCI.org. And then you can apply for a dog or, even better, you can apply to figure out a way to help this organization. A lot of people need dogs. And we love Spike. And this is his first time on "The Five." But I think he just wants Tyrus. OK, Jesse, you go next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Tyrus has a new best friend.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He loves the chicken on him -- my chicken --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just don't eat my nuggets. All right? Next, we have a bouquet gone wrong. You know how the brides throw the bouquet over, and the bridesmaids go nuts? Look at this scene. It was a wedding off Thomas and Deanna Morganthaler. I think we have the footage. And it's pretty wild.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ouch! Was that a low bridge, or did she hit her high and someone else went low?

utterances.speaker: TYRUS
utterances.utterance: Down goes Fraser. Down goes --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No one was hurt. And yes, I mean, it's competitive with the bridezillas out there, wannabe bridezillas. But everyone's OK, and happy wedding to the Morganthalers.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Indeed. All right. Kimberly, you're next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Hi. All right. So this is very cute "One More Thing." And this video shows a Houston police officer dancing with a girl who's in a wheelchair at a party.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Aww.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
